Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Dielectric-Filled Nanowaveguides for Advanced Imaging and Sensing

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
0953645
Xu

The goals of the proposed integrated research and educational activities are to advance a novel approach for super-resolution imaging and sensing using dielectric-filled nanowaveguides and to make opportunities in science and engineering education more accessible to all students, especially historically underrepresented minorities in science and engineering through undergraduate mentoring, curriculum development and outreach activities.

The research will focus on the study of optical properties of dielectric-filled nanowaveguides and the application of these nanowaveguide devices to super-resolution imaging and single molecule spectroscopy. The objectives of this research are to: (1) fabricate silicon-filled nanowaveguides and explore the possibility of other filling materials, (2) characterize in detail the far-field transmission properties and near-field intensity profiles of the nanowaveguides, (3) engineer nanowaveguide devices and test them on a near-field optical scanning microscope, and (4) apply these devices to biomedical and biotechnological research to solve challenging problems in these fields.

The objective of the educational activities is to make opportunities in science and engineering education more accessible to all students, especially historically underrepresented minorities in science and engineering. To accomplish this, the following approaches will be taken: (1) undergraduate research mentoring via one-on-one interaction between students and the PI, (2) new course development and curriculum innovation that incorporates research into teaching, and (3) outreach activities through mentor participation in programs like the Harlem Children Society and the New York State Education Department's Science & Technology Entry Program (STEP).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Light, which is electromagnetic waves by its nature with a wavelength of around 500 nanometers (one nanometer is one-billionth of a meter) for visible light, cannot pass through holes with sizes smaller than half of its wavelength according to basic electromagnetic wave theory. This phenomenon is also known as the diffraction limit, which is responsible for the imaging resolution of conventional optical microscopy at ~250 nm. The goal of the research project supported by this award is to overcome this limit by the use of nanometer-sized dielectric waveguides with appropriate choice of materials for the dielectric core and the cladding metal. 

To achieve this objective, researchers first conducted computer simulations to understand the behavior of light in nanometer-sized dielectric waveguides. They identified zinc oxide and silver as the appropriate materials for the dielectric core and the cladding metal respectively. Their analysis showed that the incident light at a wavelength around 500 nm can be efficiently guided through a 40-nanometer-diameter zinc oxide nanowaveguide in silver. Researchers then used the hydrothermal method to successfully synthesize zinc oxide nanowires with diameters ranging from 30 to 60 nanometers and fabricated zinc oxide nanowaveguides by embedding the zinc oxide nanowires in a silver film using the electroplating technique. The strong transmission of visible light through these waveguides was subsequently demonstrated in their measured optical transmission spectra. Researchers also studied other waveguide geometries including a hybrid waveguide design where light can propagate for a very long distance when confined in a nanometer-sized gap that is less than one-tenth of the incident wavelength.  These results paved the way for building innovative imaging and sensing devices with resolutions well below the diffraction limit. The findings of this research were disseminated broadly in peer-reviewed scientific journals as well as through presentations at research symposiums and international conferences.

This research has significance in both advancing basic science and enabling new technological solutions for challenging engineering and medical problems. The study of behavior of light in dielectric nanowaveguides has advanced our knowledge and understanding of optics on the nanoscale as a whole.  This research is also potentially transformative because the results obtained in this project can be used to develop innovative devices and technologies for high-resolution imaging and sensing applications. Such technologies can find a variety of applications in semiconductor industry and basic biomedical research such as high-resolution lithography and cellular imaging at the single molecule level. The innovative technologies enabled by this research could expand how science, engineering, and medicine are explored.

In addition, this research project has made opportunities in science and engineering education more accessible to many students, especially underrepresented groups in science and engineering.  Over the course of the project, more than twenty undergraduate students have worked on various parts of the project. Among these students, six are from women and underrepresented minorities. Many of these students have co-authored papers in peer-reviewed journals and have gone on to pursue graduate study at prestigious universities. The Principal Investigator of this research project has also been active in promoting science and engineering education among local high school students by providing them summer research opportunities and conducting physics workshops at local high schools. These research and training activities have provided students experiences rich in critical thinking and problem solving that will pave their way to become the nation’s next generation of scientists and engineers.
